variant.question: What should cabin crew members do if they smell smoke in the cabin, but there is NO visible sign of the source?

options.text: Shut down the air conditioning in the cabin.
Try to find the source of smoke.
Wait a couple of minutes, then it will be easier to locate the source.
Notify the pilots immediately.

variant.question: The senior cabin crew member notices traces of smoke in the passenger cabin. The source of origin can not be positively identified. The aircraft commander is notified. What will his/her action normally be after the relevant abnormal checklist has been completed?

options.text: Divert to the nearest aerodrome.
Activate the passenger oxygen system and proceed to the nearest alternate aerodrome.
Use the hand fire extinguishers by applying their contents into the area where the smoke is coming from.
Use the cargo compartment fire extinguisher since no fire is present in the cabin the cargo compartment is the most likely source of the smoke.

variant.question: If smoke appears in the air conditioning, the initial action to be taken by the flight deck crew is to:

options.text: cut off all air conditioning units.
start an emergency descent.
put on the oxygen mask and goggles.
determine the origin of the smoke.

variant.question: While flying en route, the crew observes white smoke coming out from the radar panel, situated in the middle console, with the smell of burning insulation. The recommended actions for the crew to take are:

options.text: Use the hand fire extinguisher to suppress the smoke and land immediately.
Switch off the radar, maintain safe flight conditions, and follow the checklist.
Switch off all electrical equipment, transmit a MAYDAY call, and land immediately.
Use the hand fire extinguisher to suppress the smoke and follow the checklist.

variant.question: With regard to smoke and fire in the cabin, which statement is correct?

options.text: Immediately open the cockpit security door.
Opening the checklist is the highest priority.
A MAYDAY call should be transmitted first.
The actions to be taken by the crew may be type specific.

variant.question: If a fire occurs onboard, to protect themselves from fumes and smoke before extinguishing the fire, the flight attendants should:

options.text: Cover their mouth with their hand.
Use portable O2 with mouth mask.
Cover their mouth with a dry towel.
Put on protective breathing equipment.

variant.question: During the cruise, the Senior Cabin Crew member of a jet transport aircraft reports thick grey smoke in the passenger cabin, of unknown origin, that cannot be isolated. The Commander of the aircraft, while applying the smoke-related non-normal checklist procedure, should..

options.text: open the flight deck door to equalise the pressure in the passenger cabin.
operate the cargo fire extinguisher system as the smoke comes from somewhere other than the passenger cabin.
initiate a diversion to the nearest suitable airport, without delay, in an attempt to complete the smoke procedure.
consider a landing only if the smoke source is confirmed to be on the flight deck.

variant.question: What should the cabin crew do first, following a fire in the passenger cabin?

options.text: Move passengers away from the source of the fire.
Ask the flight crew to ensure that the passenger compartment is ventilated.
Provide supplementary oxygen to those who need it.
Put on life jackets and prepare to ditch.
